title: Small business and entrepreneurship in the knowledge economy: A comparison of Australia and Sweden
abstract: Click to increase image sizeClick to decrease image size Notes The research reported in this paper was funded by an Australian Research Council grant, reference no. DP0209043. 1. While definitions of the knowledge economy vary, the term is used to capture several key trends including growth in high technology industries, the role of information and knowledge resources as factors of production, the growth of knowledge products such as business services, the importance of information and communications technologies (ICTs) and the increasing share of economic activity accounted for by small firms. See Keith Smith, ‘What is the “Knowledge Economy”? Knowledge-intensive Industries and Distributed Knowledge Bases’, paper presented to the DRUID Summer Conference on the Learning Economy, Rebild, Denmark, 15–17 June 2000. 8. For example, in the emerging biotechnology sector, it has been suggested that Australia has developed a relatively proactive model of state steering compared with a fragmented and weak state approach in Sweden. See Hans Löfgren & Mats Benner, ‘Biotechnology and Governance in Australia and Sweden: Path Dependency or Institutional Convergence?’, Australian Journal of Political Science, Vol. 38, No. 1 (2003), pp. 25–43. A further example is German biotechnology policy. Steven Casper & Hannah Kettler have shown that German public policy has compensated for disincentives for entrepreneurship in the national institutional framework, such as limited access to high risk capital, which has resulted in a hybridisation of the German business model in the biotechnology sector. In Germany, this has facilitated entrepreneurial behaviour in biotechnology within the context of a model of coordinated capitalism, which otherwise has an institutional bias towards low-risk economic behaviour. See Steven Casper & Hannah Kettler, ‘National Institutional Frameworks and the Hybridization of Entrepreneurial Business Models: The German and UK Biotechnology Sectors’, Industry and Innovation, Vol. 8, No. 1 (2001), pp. 5–31. 26. Reynolds et al., Global Entrepreneurship Monitor. 27. Verheul et al., ‘An Eclectic Theory of Entrepreneurship’, p. 14. 28. Given differences in definitions and data collection techniques in the two countries, only very general conclusions can be reached regarding the distribution of employment by size category of firms. The conclusions reached here are consistent with those from other sources that indicate that the size distribution of employment favours large firms in Sweden and small firms in Australia. See OECD, Small and Medium Enterprise Outlook (OECD, 2002), p. 242; Stevenson & Lundström, Patterns and Trends, Appendix, p. 3. 30. Reynolds et al., Global Entrepreneurship Monitor. 31. OECD, OECD Information Technology Outlook, pp. 30–3. 36. Comparison of Tables 2 and 5 should be undertaken with caution. Table 2 excludes data for the size category of firm with 0 employees. The Australian data in Table 5 includes working proprietors in firms with 0 employees. The small size category of firms in Table 5 for Australia may have an inflated share of employment compared with the national level reported in Table 2 because of this definitional difference. The difference will not be as great for Sweden, because the Swedish data in Table 5 on employees in the size category of 0 firms does not include working proprietors, making it more consistent with the figures for Table 2 which exclude employees in size category 0. Neither cross-national differences in definitions, nor differences in the databases used in Tables 2 and 5 are likely to detract from the broad conclusions reached in this paper. If anything, cross-national definitional differences (such as the narrower definition of employees, particularly in the 0 size category of firms in Sweden when compared with Australia) suggest that the conclusions reached in the article may be even stronger than the reported data indicate. 37. Hall & Soskice, Varieties of Capitalism; Richard Whitley, ‘The Institutional Structuring of Innovation Strategies: Business Systems, Firm Types and Patterns of Technical Change in Different Market Economies’, Organization Studies, Vol. 2, No. 5, pp. 855–86. 38. For a discussion of the distinction between coordinated and competitive economies see Hall & Soskice, Varieties of Capitalism; Hollingsworth & Boyer, ‘Coordination of Economic Actors’; David Soskice. ‘Divergent Production Regimes: Coordinated and Uncoordinated Market Economies in the 1980s and 1990s’, in Herbert Kitschelt, Gary Marks, Peter Lange, John D. Hall & Soskice, Varieties of Capitalism. 42. Even at a sub-sectoral level within ICT, the Swedish case does not comply with the predictions of the business systems models. As Casper & Whitley explain, there are some sub-sectors within ICT, such as application-based software, games software and secure payment systems which are characterised by high risks of competence destruction, or low technological cumulativeness in which there is high uncertainty regarding the skills and technology required for innovation. In these sub-sectors, LMEs would be expected to have an institutional strength because firms in LMEs are able to change direction rapidly and relative flexibility in their resource base, which allows them to change technological trajectories. Further, firms in LMEs are able to adopt human resource strategies that offer high rewards as compensation for the high risk of failure and job loss. However, as Casper and Whitley's data shows, despite its status as a CME, Sweden performs well in the sub-sector of middleware software which is radically innovative and involves high competence destruction risks. See Steven Casper & Richard Whitley, ‘Managing Competences in Entrepreneurial Technology Firms: A Comparative Institutional Analysis of Germany, Sweden and the UK’, Research Policy, Vol. 33, No. 1 (2004), pp. 89–106. 43. Eliasson, ‘Industrial Policy’. 48. Knowledge-intensive sectors have been defined by the OECD as those associated either with the production of technology-intensive goods or the use of high technology products and/or a high skilled workforce (see OECD, Science, Technology and Industry Outlook). OECD definitions go beyond technology- intensive sectors such as high and medium-high technology manufacturing to include business and communications services. As Keith Smith explains, the concept of the knowledge economy cannot be reduced to the level of technology intensity of industry sectors, given the ‘distributed’ nature of knowledge bases and the importance of non-R&D investments such as capital investment, training, market research for new product development and expenditure on patents and licenses. For the purpose of this paper it is not necessary to adopt a precise definition of knowledge-intensive sectors as the logic of the analysis would apply equally to firms engaged in knowledge-intensive activities, innovation and the commercialisation of new ideas in any sector. See Smith, ‘What is the “Knowledge Economy?”’, p. 13. 49. Eliasson, ‘Industrial Policy’. 50.
